transcripts.message:
28 BIllingham Street,
Somerville, Mass.

May 22, 1935.

Re: Identity of Daniel Howe (How) of Tyringham, Massachusetts, Revolutionary War Soldier.

Bureau of Pensions,
Washington, D.C.

Gentlemen:

It is desired to learn the name or names of one or both of the parents of this Daniel Howe of Tyringham, Mass.

Did this Daniel Howe or his wife receive a pension.

His service record as given in “Massachusetts Soldiers and Sailors in the War of the Revolution” Vol. VIII, p. 329, is as follows:

	"How, Daniel, Tyringham (also given Arundel). Order on Maj. Barber, payable to Lieut. John Chadwick; also, Private, Joseph Stebbens's co., Col. Jonathan Brewer's regt; muster roll Aug. 1, 1775 enlisted May 12 1775; service. 81 days; also, Company return (probably Oct., 1775); also, order of bounty coat or its equivalent in money dated Prospect Hill, Oct. 26 1775; also, return of men raised for Continental service probably from Capt. Marick’s (Herrick’s) co.; residence, Tyringham; engaged for town of Tyringham; joined Capt. Chadwick’s co., Col. Brewer’s regt; term. 3 years; also, list of men mustered between Jan. 20 1777 and June 1, 1778 by Truman Wheeler, Muster Master for Berkshire Co.; Capt. Stone's co.; also Sergeant, Capt. Dean’s co., Col. Ebenezer Sprout’s regt’ Continental Army pay accounts for service from Jan. 1, 1777, to Sept. 14, 1779; reported discharged Sept. 14, 1779; also Capt. John Chadwick’s co., Col. Brewer’s regt.; returns dated Jan. 22, 1778; residence, Arundel; enlisted for town of Tryringham; mustered by Muster Master Wheeler; reported sick at Tyringham."

It is surmised, but no proof has been found, that this Daniel Howe was the son of Daniel and Ann (Bronson) Howe, born 4 Oct. 1741 at Waterbury, Conn. and that his wife’s name was Damaris (Dutton) Howe.

Does his pension or other record give any of these data.

Respectfully

(signed)
J. Albert Holmes.

also, Capt. John Chadwick's co., Col. Brewer's regt.; return dated Jan. 22

transcripts.message:
Deposition of William HARRIS

State of Tennessee, Greene County

On this 26th day of February 1833 personally appeared before me William HARRIS a resident of Greene County and State of Tennessee aged seventy two years who being first duly sworn according to law doth on his oath make the following declaration in order to obtain the benefit of the act of Congress passed June 7th, 1832.

That he entered the service of the United States under the following named officers and served as herein stated. He entered the service of the U. S. as a private in the Company commanded by Capt. Robert BROWN in the Regiment of Colo. John SEVIER in the State of North Carolina in the year 1776 or 77 for the term of six months and served out that time and was discharged at Jonesboro, Washington County North Carolina. He further states that he has no record of his service as the place where he obtained his discharge from said Capt. BROWNS Company in Jonesboro was burned down by the British when Genl. Greene had a battle near there and he never could obtain any other discharge or certificate from said Capt. BROWN.

He further states that he lived in Washington County North Carolina until after the war and then moved to Sullivan County now Hawkins County Tennessee where he staid until 1792, at which time he removed to Greene County Tennessee where he has resided ever since. He hereby relinquishes every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present and waives all right to any other issue under the act of Congress than the present.

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year aforesaid before me

[Signed] William HARRIS
John [illegible] J.P.

State of Tennessee, Greene County

I John [illegible] Clerk of the County Court for said County do hereby certify that John [illegible], Jun. is a regularly ordained minister of the Gospel and duly authorized to administer oaths according to law and that his signature is genuine.

Given under my hand this 26th day of February 1833

[Signed] Jno [illegible] Clk
